div.p: E74/7989, unit 258, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof.
See also M to J. Francis, 13 March 1874. Melbourne

I have the honor of transmitting herewith a proof-copy of the first fascicle of the educational collections to be submitted to the hon. the Chief Secretary. The number of copies, which amidst the multifarious engagements of the Department and with hardly any means left for its working, I have been able to get ready during the season has been one hundred. As these collections as means of instruction should be accessible to the general community, I beg to suggest, that one copy should be sent to every Mechanic Institute, these places being frequented at the hours, when artisan's &c have best time for their reading and instruction.

I have also the honor to suggest, that the transmission may be effected by circular letter of your office, and in such event I will place the required copies, which will soon be ready, into the General Post Office. The means of the Department are not such, that any exterior elegance could be employed in the preparation, and I may add that the collecting was effected largely on Sundays & Holidays and the other work much in late evening hours. The greater or lesser celerity of the issue of the subsequent fascicles must depend on the support, which the Department obtains, and on the space available, the laboratory being no longer accessible to me for even these purposes.

As several amateur collectors have aided in the issue, I would respectfully suggest that a copy be presented to D. Sullivan Esq of Moiston,
Moyston, Vic?
Mr C. Walter of Anderson's Creek,
Vic.
Rev Dr Woolls, FLS., Richmond, N. S. W., and Mr C. Groener.

[...]: 'Circulars &c to certain Mechs Insts & P. Libraries 15 & 16.9.74 - H 1333.4.5'.
[...]: 'Letter Govt Botanist 21.9.74 - H 1387' [see T. Ware to M, 21 September 1874].
Ware: 'Specimen with Mr Greenwood. It is carefully got up but if not carefully handled the collection would soon fall to pieces. | TWW'.
James Francis: 'Prepare List | It would be objectionable if not impracticable to send these cumbrous packages by post but when completed they can be sent here & I can arrange delivery through the various Members of Parliament. | [J. G. F.] | 26/6/74'.
[Ware]: 'List of Mechanics Institutions &c herewith | 3/7'.
[...]: 'A book of fascicles has been sent to each of the Institutions indicated by a cross. Still there are 19 books remaining. 17.9.74'.
[...]: 'Part III now ready | Will it be necessary to forwd by circulars? | As to mode of transmissn see minute by Mr Francis of 26.6.74 | (50 Institutes will probably ask to be supplied) | [H. M. L.] | 6-9-76'.
For the distribution list, see M to T. Ware, 22 September 1874. For the text of Ware’s circular, see Williamstown chronicle, 26 September 1874, p. 3:
I have the honor to transmit for deposit in your Library a copy of the first Fascicle of an Educational Collection of Botanical Specimens, prepared by the Government Botanist, with a view to supplying means of instruction in the first principles of Botany for all persons in this community who are desirous of entering upon the study of that useful branch of science.
